title: The Big Midweek
author: Steve Hanley, Olivia Piekarski
notes: Easy read, and revealing perspective that gives a bigger picture of The Fall. Nice to get a sense of how there were more talented people that came together and made it happen, and that MES needed them as much as they him. Reticent as he is to talk about himself you get some glimpses of self refelction, but mainly told deadpan and  all the better for it.
Subtitle: Life Inside The Fall

title: Periodic Tales
author: Hugh Aldersey-Williams
notes: Enjoyed it, but felt that it wasn't the best format - feltlike it could've been a series of distinct articles - found it hard to retain much by the end. Probably my fault for rushing.
Subtitle: The Curious Lives of the Elements

title: The Forensic Records Society
author: Magnus Mills
notes: Lovely little allegory - clear enough even for me to get it, and nice details.Slightly ran out of steam.

title: Angry White Pyjamas
author: Robert Twigger
notes: Interesting journey and examination of his reasons for doing the training as well and interrogating others reasons. Nice pen portraits of all the people. Alos interesting ideas of the Japanese culture.'torture disguised as celebration'
Subtitle: A normal bloke becomes a deadly weapon

title: 25 Years of VIZ
author: William Cook
notes: Writer was a bit too much of a fan, but interesting to see just how long they'd been at it before it got really big. Good variety of artwork and behind the scenes of the creation.

title: Madly,Deeply
author: Alan Rickman
notes: Took a while to understand that despite a seemingly endless succession of meals and names his obsession for the work came through, and he obviously really loved the work, and most of the things around it. Very much a shorthand style compared to the brief selection of angsty early diaries. Became more affecting has his mortality became more apparent, even though it wasn't mentioned. An insight to a type of self reflective diary - not necessarily one meant for publication.
Subtitle: The Alan Rickman Diaries

title: Out
author: Kirino
notes: Very much liked the characters and kept me interested all the way through.

title: The Underground Railroad
author: Colston Whitehead
notes: Rattled through it  - characters grabbed me to pay attention to the horrors of slavery, beyond the 'yeah slavery is bad' to the specifics and then laid bare via the different situations and chapters. All very good.

title: Grunt
author: Mary Roach
notes: Great fun. Really liked how she wrote it, Breezy and Informative, funny and curious.
Subtitle: The Curious Science of Humans at War

title: Hellstrom's Hive
author: Frank Herbert
notes: Petered out slightly but enjoyed a bit of old school, sort of near future hard traditional SciFi

title: The Female Man
author: Joanna Russ
notes: Could only make sense of it by cribbing the wikipedia entry and wasn't worth the bother

title: Put me back on my bike
author: William Fotheringham
notes: Good on the context of the time ands eemed like e well rounding picture of the man.

title: Marabou Stork Nightmares
author: Irvine Welsh
notes: Funny and strange start. As it went on you wondered where it was all going, kind of knowing that it wouldn't end well, but I wasn't quite prepared with the sharp turn to nasty and brutal. Felt like an authentic ending.

title: Dead Famous
author: Greg Jenner
notes: Caught myself and got bored of the topic.

title: Pain
author: Patrick Wall
notes: Started interesting and then got more wooly and unfocused. Became quite dull.
Subtitle: The Science of Suffering

title: Spoon Fed
author: Tim Spector
notes: One of those that could probably be a bit condensed - but interesting opinions about diet and nutrition, that we have to wait for the science to see how prescient they are.
Subtitle: Why Almost Everything We've Been Told About Is Wrong

title: Just Enough Research
author: Erika Hall
notes: Not really what I was after.

title: Going to Sea in a Sieve
author: Danny Baker
notes: Fun - nicely written on how he ended up in and around music - especially froma working class background.

title: Ring for Jeeves
author: Pelham G. Wodehouse
notes: Enjoyable as always but no Wooster does leave a little whole. This all came together in the end satisfactorily, but not with the usual panache.

title: The Status Game
author: Will Storr
notes: Was keen to read this, as it's a fascinating subject. It's a useful lense to apply to how people behave. Great on the different types of status games, and how they happen in different proportions in a variety of situations.
Subtitle: On Human Life and How to Play It

title: Happy Now
author: Charlie Higson
notes: Mental - took some turns and then some more.

title: Touching from a distance
author: Deborah Curtis
notes: Honest perspective of a figure often mythologised due to his early death.
Subtitle: Ian Curtis and Joy Division

title: Lost at Sea
author: Jon Ronson
notes: Enjoyable variety.
Subtitle: The Jon Ronson Mysteries

title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
author: Jennifer Egan
notes: Wasn't sure how I'd get on with the shifting timelines and characters, sometimes hard to follow what's happening to who, but then it all seems to coalesce and the threads draw together. Especially liked the slide pages, which could have been gimmicky , but they worked and felt like an authentic voice.

title: Bedsit Disco Queen
author: Tracey Thorn
notes: Starting a trend for me of reading musicians biogs - enjoy how they discover music and are often incredibly surprised by their own success.
Subtitle: How I Grew Up and Tried to be a Pop Star

title: King of the Ants
author: Charlie Higson
notes: Pretty brutal.

title: Why We Sleep
author: Matthew Walker
notes: Interesting things in it, but spoiled somewhat by him overreaching on some things and cherry picking others.
Subtitle: The New Science of Sleep and Dreams

title: Psmith, Journalist
author: Pelham G. Wodehouse
notes: Either you think the prose is charmingly and cleverly witty and amusing or you don't I do. Does show it's a age a little with the occasional phrase or word that pulls one up short, but japes ensue with much mirth.

title: Nutshell
author: Ian McEwen
notes: I imagine that the premise, whilst great, could've been handled badly and gone wrong. But it's really good. Lovely balance between ruminations and moving the plot along. Enjoyed.
